instruction: How did the researchers determine the best features to use for mapping the selected grasslands habitats using the automated RFE-RF system?
Output: The researchers determined the best features to use for mapping the selected grasslands habitats using the automated RFE-RF system by employing recursive feature elimination (RFE) in combination with random forest (RF) classification. They used multiple acquisitions of hyperspectral (HS) and LiDAR data and computed several LiDAR-based products and different spectral indices (SI). These LiDAR-based products and spectral indices were then used as input in the RFE-RF system. The system automatically selected the optimal features based on their ability to enhance the classification accuracy. The researchers found that the inclusion of LiDAR and spectral indices significantly improved the classification accuracy, indicating the importance of using LiDAR in combination with HS data. From the selected optimal features, which were strongly linked to the heterogeneous characteristics of the habitats and landscapes, the researchers were able to achieve high classification results, suggesting that the selected Natura 2000 meadows and dry grasslands habitats can be accurately mapped using airborne HS and LiDAR data.

instruction: Can the combination of recursive feature elimination (RFE) and random forest (RF) classification be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for mapping selected Natura 2000 grasslands habitats using hyperspectral (HS) and LiDAR data?
Output: Yes, the combination of recursive feature elimination (RFE) and random forest (RF) classification can be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for mapping selected Natura 2000 grasslands habitats using hyperspectral (HS) and LiDAR data.
